properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Slippery road conditions are expected. A low pressure system over New England will give flurries at times heavy tonight. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm locally are expected. These conditions could cause rapidly deteriorating driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T12:19:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T20:20:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0106609418.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific front will move into the Peace River region early on Friday morning. This will be followed by an Arctic front pushing through the region in the afternoon and then stalling on Saturday. Long periods of snow at times mixed with rain are expected with total accumulation of 20 to 30 cm possible by Saturday evening. Snow will begin over the Williston region today then change to rain or snow mixed with rain tonight as the warm Pacific front approaches. Rain mixed with snow is expected to develop tonight over the southern Peace River region then change to snow Friday when the Arctic front pushes through. The northern Peace River region will likely stay north of the warm front and receive the highest amount of snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T09:59:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T18:00:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3962002164.2019
Area: Williston, B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific frontal system will move into the northern BC interior Friday morning. This system will be followed by an Arctic front pushing through the region on Friday afternoon and then stalling over the region on Saturday. Long periods of snow are expected with total snowfall amounts of 30 to 40 cm forecast by Saturday evening. Snow will begin over Pine Pass today and will continue tonight. There is also a risk of freezing rain tonight for Pine Pass. 5 to 10 cm of snow is forecast tonight. However the more significant snowfall is expected on Friday night and Saturday. The snow will taper to flurries on Saturday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T09:45:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T17:46:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2469911435.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert For Portions Of The Red River
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Red River from St. Jean Baptiste through the City of Winnipeg (except for Ste. Agathe) due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-08T15:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-07T13:58:30-06:00, B1B2DD07-99AD-6454-6156-329B200DBADB
Area: The Red River from St. Jean Baptiste through the City of Winnipeg except for Ste. Agathe
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and poor driving conditions expected. Total snowfall: near 15 cm except locally up to 25 cm over higher terrain. Locations: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Green Bay - White Bay, Grand Falls-Windsor and Buchans. Time span: Friday morning through Friday evening. Remarks: Snowfall accumulations are likely to vary considerably with the highest amounts expected through Badger, Buchans, inland and higher elevations of Burgeo highway, Green Bay - White Bay and higher elevations between Deer Lake and Corner Brook and Deer Lake and Gros Morne. Areas near the coast and in lower lying areas through the Humber Valley are likely to see much lower amounts. The snow will taper off Friday evening but flurries, snow squalls, and strong westerly winds will develop again early Saturday along the west coast and persist through the day. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-08T11:25:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T19:26:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3506212775.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for today through Friday. Flurries and local snow squalls are developing off Georgian Bay and Lake Huron and are expected to continue intermittently through Friday afternoon. While the heaviest snow squalls are expected to remain south and east of the Bruce Peninsula, portions of the Peninsula can expect locally heavy snow and reduced visibilities at times making travel difficult. Motorists are advised to watch for quickly changing weather conditions and adjust their driving accordingly. Local snowfall accumulations of 5 to 15 cm will be possible. If the snow squalls look to be more intense or persistent than currently forecast, a snow squall warning may be required for the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T12:21:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T20:22:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2577277887.2019
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. An unstable airmass will settle over James Bay and will cause coastal snowsqualls beginning Friday. These localized snowfalls could give accumulations of 15 to 25 cm and greatly reduce visibilities over these areas. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T12:15:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T20:16:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2865283996.2019
Area: James Bay and La Grande River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly up to 110 km/h except 130 km/h in the Canada Bay area. Locations: Great Northern Peninsula and the Northeast Coast. Time span: today. Remarks: The wind gusts of 100 km/h or higher will start to diminish near noon in the Gros Morne area and later this afternoon elsewhere, except in the Canada Bay area where they will persist until after midnight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-08T05:59:54-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather expected for parts of Nova Scotia Friday night into Saturday. A low pressure system is bring some rain to the province tonight and Friday. Colder air will move in behind this system on Friday. As this colder air arrives from the northwest, showers will turn to periods of snow late Friday afternoon or Friday evening. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 centimetres are possible for most of the province in the northerly onshore flow, with the highest amounts expected over northern Nova Scotia, where locally total amounts could reach near 15 centimetres by Saturday morning. As this will be the first potentially significant snowfall across parts of the province, the travelling public are urged to use caution and prepare for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T11:41:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T19:42:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2353612907.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. An approaching warm front will track across the BC interior today. The warm air aloft combined with near or below zero temperatures at the surface will result in periods of freezing rain this afternoon. The freezing rain is expected to change to rain late this afternoon as temperatures rise above zero. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T02:59:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T22:14:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2211988669.2019
Area: Bulkley Valley, Lakes District, Stuart - Nechako
properties.Author: Environment Canada

Remarks: Winds are beginning to diminish this evening, but strong gusts are still possibly, especially along exposed areas of the coast. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 70 mm can be expected by early Friday evening. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Intense snow squalls late this afternoon through Friday. Snow squalls will develop off southern Lake Huron late this afternoon and then intensify tonight. These snow squalls will be capable of producing significant snowfall accumulations tonight with local amounts up to 25 cm possible. Strong winds will accompany these snow squalls resulting in blowing snow and significantly reduced visibilities at times. Conditions will slowly improve through the day Friday, though additional significant snowfall accumulations will be possible. Total snowfall accumulations of 30 to 40 cm locally will be possible by time the snow squalls weaken Friday evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T12:20:39-00:00

Area: Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County

properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry conditions expected across the Island late Friday afternoon and Friday night. A low pressure system is currently giving periods of rain or wet snow to the province tonight. Rain may changeover to primarily snow over Prince County overnight before ending Friday morning. Much colder air will begin moving in from the north later in the day Friday, with periods of snow developing Friday evening which may given accumulations of up to 5 centimetres by Saturday morning. As this will be the first significant snowfall across much of the province, the travelling public are urged to use caution and prepare for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow expected for much of New Brunswick tonight and/or Friday. A low pressure system is currently giving snow to northern New Brunswick and rain to southern sections, with the rain/snow boundary currently located along a line roughly between Woodstock and Miramichi. This boundary will slide southward tonight, and thus rain will change to periods of snow over the remainder of the province by early Friday morning. Periods of snow will redevelop or persist mainly over eastern and southern parts of the province on Friday before easing off later in the day. Snowfall amounts across the province will range between 2 and 10 centimetres, with the highest amounts expected over eastern sections on Friday, where locally total amounts could reach near 15 centimetres over higher terrain. As this will be the first significant snowfall across much of the province, the travelling public are urged to use caution and prepare for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T11:37:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T19:38:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2741815336.2019
